context: Til he com to the derk valeie
And farwel, sweet, my worldes blisse!
The most pitee, the moste routhe,°
¶But at the last, to sayn right sothe
For fals Fortune hath pleide a game
¶“A! good sir!” quod I, “Say not so!
Trewly, the fairest companye
To mak that fair, that trewly she
Was hir chief patrone° of beaute
Had that sweet, my lives leche!°
Had that sweet, that boon nor brekke°
She wolde have be, at the lest
As for the fairest and the beste.
The gladdest and the moste at reste.°
Ther is, at the west side of Itaille
Upon Grisilde, this poor creature
That may be founde, as fer as last Itaille.°
So spradde of hire heigh bountee the fame
Ne of hir heigh estaat no remembraunce
So noble array in al West Lumbardie.
And more plesant, for hir heigh linage;
He that semeth the wisest, by Jhesus!
God kepe us from his fals dissimulinge!°
This fals chanoun, the foule feend him fecche!°
Than had this preest this sory° craft to lere;°
Quod the chanoun, “and farwel, grant mercy!”
“Tel me the name of the privy° stoon?”
Hir frendes, which that° knewe hir hevy° thoght
Of swich a parfit wis God and a stable,°
That thou it madest lik to thin own merk.°
¶“Aurelie,” quod she, “by heigh God above
The hyest rokke in Armorik Briteine;
That loveth thee, as his own hertes lif.
The grettest that ever were seyn with eye.
To been defouled° with mannes foul delit
“What seith Omer of good Penalopee?
Trouthe is the hyest thing that man may kepe”:—
Amid° the toun, right in the quikkest° strete
‘Brother,’ quod he, ‘fer in the north contree
¶“ ‘Pay me,’ quod he, ‘or by the sweet Seinte Anne
For his science, and for his heigh renoun
If that he faught, and had the hyer hond
He which that hath the shortest shal biginne.
Of al the Troyan nacioun
Of the Troyan Eneas
O, sooth is, every thing is wist,°
Fulliche of al his greet trespas
Seint Julian, lo, bon hostel!°
The castel-yate° on my right hond
Fulle of the finest stones° faire
Of iren, he, the gret Omere;°
The harm, the gretest wikkednesse
The eldest lady of hem alle spak
Which of the castel was the chief dongeoun,°
Of hir that rometh in the yonder place;
Now certes, fals Arcite, thou shalt nat so.
For I dar noght biknowe° min owen name;
And thou hast maked him thy chief squier;
A citole° in hir right hand hadde she
Al ful of chirking° was that sory place.
Armed Compleint,° Outhees,° and Fiers Outrage.
With alle the rites of his paien wise.°
“The lord hath of his heigh discrecioun°
Of good Arcite may best ymaked be
With cloth of gold, the richest that he hadde.
Upon the right hond wente old Egeus
Upon the right hond wente old Egeus
Upon the left hand, with a loud shoutinge
That good Arcite, of chivalrië flour
The yongest man that is in al this route°
That haddest him for thy ful frend received?
What for his strengthe, and for his heigh bountee,°
The fairest children of the blood royal
That was the wisest child of everichoon;°
But ones, for it was hir plein° entente°
His comb was redder than the fin° coral
And at the west gate of the toun,’ quod he
Unto the west gate of the toun, and fond
O newe Scariot,° new Genilon!
False dissimilour,° O Greek Sinon
Han in min hous ybeen, to my gret ese;°
That all the grettest that were of that lond
The proudest° of thise riotoures three
I yow assoile,° by min heigh power
Thou woldest make me kisse thin old breech,°
Cam of the bitter goddesse Jalousie.
But I dar seyn, I am hir trewest man
Biforn the chief auter,° whil the mass laste
I is ful wight,° God waat,° as is a ra;°
I is thin awen clerk, swa have I sel!”°
That lasse lust° hath to that sory pley.°
This maiden bright Cecilie, as hir lif seith
The last Idus of March,° after° the yeer.
They demen° gladly° to the badder ende.°
As wisly helpe me gret God of kinde!°
So ferde it by this fers and proude knight;
Founde oon the best, and lengest time abiden
Thin hevy charge; it shal the lasse dere.
Adieu! be glad! God spede us bothe two!
From Troilus, and eek his greet emprise;
What? bet than swiche five? Ey, nay, ywis!
“A! Lord! what me is tid a sory chaunce!
Til at the laste, “O good eem,” quod she tho
“Now set a cas, the hardest is, ywis
Or love the wers, though wrecches on it cryen?
“Ye, wis,” quod fresh Antigone the white
Til at the last the dede sleep hir hente.
First he gan hir his right lady calle
And seide, “Now is this the grettest wonder
The yonder hous, that stant aforyein us?”
Of his good wil, and doth him not to deie.
For, pardee, sik is he that is in sorwe.
She com to diner in hir plain entente.
Wheras at leiser al this heigh matere
His privé coming, and the siker place
Now is this bet, than bothe two be lorn!
For every bore hath oon of thy bright yën!
“But nathelees, min owen lady bright
Retorned to his real palais, sone
For of fortunes sharp adversitee
The worst kinde of infortune is this
He is eek oon the grettest of this toun;
That yeven signes of the bitter peine
Til at the last this sorwful wight Criseyde
“And at that corner, in the yonder hous
The blisful soun; and, in that yonder place
“And to the yonder hille I gan hire gide
“I am right sory Troilus wol deie.”
His greet estat, and peril of the toun
And my good word, al sholde I liven ever.
Lay kissing ay his lady bright Criseyde:
“My lady bright Criseyde hath me bitrayed
God wot I wende, O lady bright, Criseyde
That bereth the red hepe.°
And thurgh his fair beringe.°
For his crisp° heer, shininge as gold so fin
And priketh° his blind hors over the falwes,°
¶“ ‘Taak fir,° and ber it in the derkest hous
